title: Kenya: Panic As Teachers Dig in Over Strike
text:
"We must explore all avenues and we need two weeks to talk with the National Treasury, Education ministry, Teachers Service Commission and the Budget Committee," said Ms Chege. 
The commission needs Sh17 billion to increase salaries for the 288,060 teachers, backdated to July 2013. 
OUT OF PATIENCE 
Knut secretary-general Wilson Sossion told the committee that teachers had run out of patience and the National Executive Council will meet on Thursday to endorse the strike. 
"We want to make it clear that teachers will not report to school in September," he said. 
Last week the teachers' employer moved to the Supreme Court seeking to hold up the 50-60 per cent increase awarded by the Labour Court and upheld by Court of Appeal. 
On Wednesday, Mr Sossion told the committee that irrespective of Thursday's decision by the Supreme Court, teachers will go on strike unless the increase is reflected in the August payslip. 
Mr Sossion was with chairman Mudzo Nzili, treasurer John Matiangi and deputy secretary-general Hesbon Otieno. 
DOUBLE STANDARDS 
Ms Chege expressed disquiet over what she said were the double standards of the salaries team after it came to light that a clerical officer at the commission earns more than a P1 teacher. 
However, she said: "We do not need to paralyse learning and interfere with examinations." 
She accused the Teachers Service Commission of failing to honour court orders such as the retired teacher's case which has been dragging since 1997. 
Matayos MP Godfrey Odanga also accused the commission of dashing from one court to another without asking Parliament and the National Treasury. 
Mr Odanga said teachers deserve better pay. 
Mr Sossion told the MPs that teachers should now be enjoying a 68 per cent salary increase. 
"We are already two years late in signing a collective bargaining agreement, which is unconstitutional. We have been patient since 2013 and we will not accept anything less," said Mr Sossion. More on This
